title: From Knowledge Generation to Knowledge Verification: Examining the BioMedical Generative Capabilities of ChatGPT
author: Ahmed Abdeen Hamed (MGEN – College of Engineering, Northeastern University Miami), Byung Suk Lee (Department of Computer Science, University of Vermont), ..., Haohe Liu (CASCI Laboratory, Binghamton University)
relevance_why: This work involves the verification of biomedical knowledge generated by ChatGPT, which could apply methodologies relevant to quality verification of audio and language models that Haohe Liu works with.
background: The paper presents a structured evaluation framework for assessing the accuracy of biomedical associations generated by a large language model, specifically targeting relationships between diseases and relevant entities.
contribution: This paper introduces a structured approach to verify the biomedical terms generated by ChatGPT, achieving high term accuracy rates and literature coverage for disease-centric associations.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods in biomedical knowledge verification typically depended on manual checks or lacked systematic frameworks for validation.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves on those approaches by automating the verification process using biomedical ontologies and literature, resulting in high accuracy rates.

key_innovation: The integration of prompt engineering with ontology verification to enhance the reliability of biomedical knowledge generation.
real_world_impact: The methodologies proposed could streamline the validation of biomedical research outputs, ultimately improving the credibility of AI-generated medical data and its applications in healthcare.
limitations: The paper notes that symptoms are less accurately identified and that there may be inconsistencies in generated ontology term IDs.

new_terms.prompt engineering: **Prompt engineering** is the practice of designing the inputs given to a language model to elicit the most relevant and useful responses, thereby influencing the quality of the generated outputs.
new_terms.biomedical ontologies: **Biomedical ontologies** are structured frameworks that represent knowledge about biological and medical concepts, enabling computational reasoning and information retrieval.
